items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
		 
Item:  9.02
		 
		 
TO:
Board of Trustees
					 
					 
FROM: 
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
					 
					 
PREPARED BY:
Juan Cruz, Associate Superintendent of Educational Services, Kirsten King, Director of Instructional Services and Lucretia Peebles, Ph.D., Administrator for Charter School Oversight
					 
					 
SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action of the East Side Union High School District's Request to Amend the Term of the Luis Valdez Leadership Academy Charter (aka Latino College Preparatory Academy II)
		 
1.  Brief Introduction and Summary of Recommendation
		 
On August 22, 2013, the East Side Union High School District Board of Trustees (Board) conditionally approved the charter petition for Latino College Preparatory Academy II (aka Luis Valdez Leadership Academy), granting the NHU Foundation permission to operate the Luis Valdez Leadership Academy (LVLA) within the boundaries of the East Side Union High School District, located in San Jose, California, for a term of two years, beginning on August 22, 2013, and ending on June 30, 2015. LVLA opened on the Yerba Buena High School campus on August 11, 2014, offering only the ninth grade. The school will add a grade each year to reach its full complement of grades (9-12) and enrollment capacity of 400 students. The current enrollment at LVLA is 93 students.
		 
The Board conditionally approved the charter petition for LVLA based on the District Administration’s concerns regarding “[The NHU Foundation’s] ability to implement the stated college preparatory program.” Moreover, the District Administration had “questions and concerns” regarding The NHU Foundation’s ability to “successfully implement the program set forth in the LCPA II petition….” The Board’s conditional approval included specific dates by which The NHU Foundation was to meet each condition.
		 
The NHU Foundation met the Board-specified approval conditions for LVLA within the agreed upon timeline. During the 2013-14 and 2014-15 school years, District staff has monitored the Latino College Preparatory Academy program and noted, not only that the educational program has improved, but also The NHU Foundation appears to be committed to offering a high quality educational program to students who attend its Latino College Preparatory Academy.   
		 
Education Code § 47607 (a) (3) (A) establishes or sets forth as the most important criterion that a school board must consider in the renewal of a charter school, the school’s ability to show evidence of increased student achievement for all of its significant subgroups. LVLA opened its doors on August 11, 2014, and cannot provide sufficient evidence to meet this criterion before the charter expiration date, June 30, 2015.
		 
The District Administration requests that the Board amend the term of the LVLA by three years to provide LVLA the full five-year term to collect student achievement data required by statute for renewal.    
		 
		 
FISCAL IMPACT:
N/A
		 
FUNDING SOURCE:
N/A
		 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees review and consider the District Administration's recommendation to amend the current two-year term of the Luis Valdez Leadership Academy Charter (to expire on June 30, 2015) to extend the charter by three years to end on June 30, 2018.
items.item_recommendation: It is recommended that the Board of Trustees review and consider the District Administration's recommendation to amend the current two-year term of the Luis Valdez Leadership Academy Charter (to expire on June 30, 2015) to extend the charter by three years to end on June 30, 2018.

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  12.01
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM: 
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action Approving Statement of Votes and Certification of Election Results from the Santa Clara County Registrar of Voters Office and Declare the Totals to be the Final Results of the Election; Approval and Adoption of Resolution #2014/2015-09 Certifying to the Board of Supervisors of Santa Clara County all Proceedings in the November 4, 2014, General Obligation Bond Election; Adopt Resolution #2014/2015-10 Designating the Citizens Bond Oversight Committee for the Bonds authorized under Measure I
	 
	 
Attached are the Certificate of Election Results, Official Results, Statement of Votes and Certificate of Election/Oaths of Office from the November 4, 2014, General Election.  Pursuant to Elections Code 15400, the Board is to accept the Statement of Votes and Certification of Election Results, and declare the totals to be the final results of the election and that J. Manuel Herrera, Frank Biehl and Van Le, the persons having the highest number of votes for the offices of Governing Board Members and also declare the results of each election under its jurisdiction as to each measure voted on at the election.
	 
Pursuant to Education Code section 15274, the Governing Board shall cause an entry of the fact of the passage of Measure I by greater than 55% of the vote to be made upon the Board’s minutes and to certify such fact to the County Board of Supervisors and to request that the County Superintendent of Schools send a copy of the certificate of election results to the County Board of Supervisors.  The attached proposed Resolution #2014/2015-09 accomplishes these purposes.
	 
In addition, pursuant to Education Code Section 15278, the Governing Board must designate a bond oversight committee.  The attached proposed Resolution #2014/2015-10 accomplishes this legal requirement.
	 
	 
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees:  (i) approve the attached Statement of Votes and Certification of Election Results from the Santa Clara County Registrar of Voters Office and declare the totals to be the final results of the Election; (ii) approve and adopt Resolution #2014/2015-09 Certifying to the Board of Supervisors of Santa Clara County all Proceedings in the November 4, 2014, General Obligation Bond Election, and; (iii) adopt Resolution #2014/2015-10 Designating the Citizens Bond Oversight Committee for the Bonds authorized under Measure I.

J. Manuel Herrera, Board Trustee
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action regarding Pending Board Vacancy: Process for Appointment and Provisional Appointment to the Governing Board
	 
	 
Board Member Carrasco’s election to the San Jose City Council will result in a vacancy on the Governing Board for the remainder of Member Carrasco’s term.
	 
Board Bylaw 9223 (a copy of which is attached) specifies the process for provisional appointments to the Governing Board. Per Board Bylaw 9223, when a vacancy occurs four or more months before the end of a Board member's term, the Board shall, within 60 days of the date of the vacancy or the filing of the member's deferred resignation, either order an election or make a provisional appointment. If no election is ordered, then the Board will make a provisional appointment.
	 
Board Bylaw 9223 specifies that the Board shall advertise in the local media to solicit “candidate applications or nominations.” Thus, the Board must decide whether it will seek applications or nominations for the upcoming Board vacancy. Per Board Bylaw 9223, the Board must also establish the timeline and the rules for the selection of the provisional appointees, and approve an application and a set of questions for all candidates to answer in writing. The Board must also appoint an ad hoc committee consisting of less than a quorum of the Board to ensure that applicants are eligible for Board membership as required by law. The applications of all eligible candidates will be forwarded to all Board members. The Board may appoint an advisory committee to, at a public meeting, review applications, interview candidates and make recommendations to the Board. The Board is not restricted by the advisory committee’s recommendation and may appoint any of the eligible applicants. The Board shall interview the candidates, of it’s choosing from the list of eligible applicants, at a public meeting, accept oral or written public input, and select the provisional appointee by a majority vote.
		 
	 
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees establish the timeline and rules for the selection of the provisional appointee; approve an application and a set of questions for all candidates to answer in writing; and appoint an advisory committee to, at a public meeting, review applications, interview candidates and make recommendations to the Board.
items.item_recommendation: It is recommended that the Board of Trustees establish the timeline and rules for the selection of the provisional appointee; approve an application and a set of questions for all candidates to answer in writing; and appoint an advisory committee to, at a public meeting, review applications, interview candidates and make recommendations to the Board.

TO:
Board of Trustees
					 
					 
FROM:
Frank Biehl, Board Trustee
					 
					 
SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action regarding Call for Nominations to CSBA Delegate Assembly
		 
		 
The California School Boards Association (CSBA) is currently accepting nominations for the CSBA Delegate Assembly.  Any CSBA member board is eligible to nominate board members within their geographical region or subregion.  Boards may nominate as many individuals as it chooses by submitting a nomination form for each nominee.  All nominees must serve on CSBA member boards and give their approval prior to being nominated to CSBA's Delegate Assembly.
		 
All nominees must submit a one-page, single-sided, candidate biographical sketch form.  An optional one-page, one-sided resume (resume cannot be substituted for the candidate biographical sketch form).  All nominations must be postmarked by the United States Postal Office no later than Tuesday, January 7, 2015.  Faxes are also acceptable, but must be received by January 7, 2015.  It is the nominee’s responsibility to confirm that all nomination materials have been received by the CSBA Leadership Services department by this due date. Late submissions will not be accepted.
		 
Elected Delegates will serve a two-year term, beginning April 1, 2015, through March 31, 2017.  There are two required Delegate Assembly meetings each year, one on May 16-17, 2015, in Sacramento and one on December 2-3, 2015, preceding the CSBA Annual Education Conference and Trade Show in San Diego.
		 
		 
		 
		 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Expenses to attend required meetings
		 
FUNDING SOURCE:
General Fund
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees consider submitting nomination(s) to the CSBA Delegate Assembly.

Item:  12.05
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM: 
Frank Biehl, Board Trustee
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action to Adopt Resolution #2014/2015-12 in Opposition to the Use of Pepper Spray in Santa Clara County Court Schools
	 
	 
East Side Union High School District supports the right of students and staff to attend schools that are safe and provide school environments that ensure both the physical and emotional safety of students and staff. 
	 
East Side Union High School District desires to provide a safe learning environment for incarcerated youth. The use of oleoresin capsicum commonly referred to as pepper spray has been authorized for use by probation staff at the Santa Clara County Court Schools.
	 
A national survey by the Council of Juvenile Correctional Administrators (CJCA) found that only 29% of juvenile facilities in the United States authorize the use of chemical restraints at all, and only 8% of juvenile facilities participating in the CJCA Performance-based Standards reported any use of pepper spray.  Thus, use of pepper spray is both unnecessary and out of step with accepted professional practice.
	 
East Side Union High School District believes pepper spray use is potentially dangerous and harmful to the health and safety of the staff and students at the Santa Clara County Court Schools.
	 
	 
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees adopt Resolution #2014/2015-12 in Opposition to the Use of Pepper Spray in Santa Clara County Court Schools.

PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, and Karen Poon, Director of Finance
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Presentation, Discussion and/or Action to Receive and Approve First Interim Financial Report for Fiscal Year 2014/2015
	 
	 
This is the first of two interim reports to be presented to the Governing Board for the 2014-15 fiscal year.  The report provides the Board with the financial status of the District as of October 31, 2014.  This report is presented to the Board to provide the current fiscal status of the District and to meet the fiscal accountability requirements of AB 1200.  
	 
Included in the attachments are an executive summary which summarizes the financial data from the Standardized Account Code Structure (SACS) reporting system and budget assumptions that provide the basis for determining the District’s fiscal status.  In addition, there are supporting documentation and comparative analysis of the 2014/15 Adopted Budget vs. First Interim update as of October 31, 2014, multi-year projections, State reporting forms, and other related documents.  These documents and worksheets serve as tools to certify the ongoing fiscal health of the District for this current year, as well as the two subsequent fiscal years.  
	 
California school district revenues and expenditures are subject to constant change.  School district budgets are not static documents, but instead are constantly revised to respond to decisions and actions at the State, local, and Federal levels.  The First Interim Report financial projections have been updated to reflect new information received and Board actions taken since the budget was adopted.  
	 
Education Code Section 42131 requires that the Governing Board of each school district certify in writing within 45 days after the close of the period being reported whether or not the school district is able to meet its financial obligations for the remainder of the fiscal year and subsequent two fiscal years.  The certification is classified as either positive, qualified, or negative.   
	 
Based on the District's First Interim report and multi-year projections as of October 31, 2014, I am recommending that the Board approve the attached positive certification for the East Side Union High School District.  Board approval will provide certification to the State ensuring that the District is able to meet its financial obligations for the current fiscal year and subsequent two fiscal years
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Not Applicable
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Not Applicable
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the positive certification of the First Interim Financial Report to the operating budget as presented for fiscal year 2014/2015.

Item:  14.03
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM: 
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, and Karen Poon, Director of Finance
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action to Approve One Day Material Decrease of School Attendance for Oak Grove High School due to a San Jose Police Standoff near the School on November 19, 2014
	 
	 
The California Department of Education Form J-13A, Request for Allowance of Attendance because of Emergency Conditions, is being submitted for Board review and approval.  A material decrease in Average Daily Attendance (ADA) occurred on November 19, 2014, due to San Jose Police activity involving an overnight and into the morning standoff nearby Oak Grove High School.  San Jose Police notified the principal of the school that there was a police situation in a home near the campus and recommended the students not report to school until the situation was handled and/or under control.  The incident caused the suspension of morning classes.  Once clearance was given, the campus reopened at 9:15 a.m. and notifications were sent out by TeleParent, school website and news media for student's to return and/or come to school.  The school remained opened for the remainder of the day, but not without causing a significant drop in the daily attendance for Wednesday, November 19, 2014, which caused the student attendance (ADA) to be materially affected.
	 
The estimated average daily attendance (ADA) decrease on November 19, 2014, is expected to be 6.8, which is approximately $58,130.00.
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Estimated ADA 6.8 or approximately $58,130.00
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
General Fund
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve submission of Form J-13A for the one day material decrease of average daily attendance (ADA) on Wednesday, November 19, 2014, for Oak Grove High School.

TO:

FROM:

PREPARED BY:
Juan Cruz, Associate Superintendent of Educational Services
					 
SUBJECT:
Approve CAHSEE Local Waivers for Special Education Students 
	 
DESCRIPTION:
Education Code Section 60851 states that students who take one or both parts of the CAHSEE with a modification and receive the equivalent of a passing score are eligible for the waiver request process.  At the request of the student's parent or guardian, a school principal must submit to the local school governing board a request for a waiver of the requirement to pass the part(s) of the CAHSEE on which a modification was used and the equivalent of a passing score was earned.  For the local board to waive the CAHSEE requirement, the principal must certify to the local board that the pupil has all of the following:
An individualized education program adopted pursuant to the federal Individuals with Disabilities Education Act or a plan adopted pursuant to Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973 that requires the accommodations or modifications to be provided to the pupil when taking the high school exit examination.
Sufficient high school level coursework either satisfactorily completed or in progress in a high school level curriculum sufficient to have attained the skills and knowledge otherwise needed to pass the high school exit examination.
An individual score report for the pupil showing that the pupil has received the equivalent of a passing score on the high school exit examination while using a modification that fundamentally alters what the high school exit examination measures as determined by the State Board of Education.
The waivers were requested by the school site administration on behalf of the students's parents.
	 
The recommended waivers meet the aforementioned criteria delineated in the Education Code 60851:
	 
                         Student A            Student B            Student C            Student D             Student E            
                         Student F            Student G            Student H            Student I              Student J            
                         Student K            Student L            Student M            Student N             Student O
                         Student P            Student Q
 
FISCAL IMPACT:
N/A
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
N/A
	  
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the recommended waivers.
